channel.title: Does your success come from school?
channel.description:
I've posted this on Moparscape, but Fat_Cookies suggested I try this discussion as well as a few others on Moparisthebest. I figured I'd get better responses as well, so...
School is a source of education. But, not everyone pursues the rest of their life based on what they learn in their classes. To some people, the classes they've taken in school were just as valuable as lunch.
Do you believe your grade in school defines how intelligent you are? Does it truly affect your future and opportunity toward success, or is it only a stepping stone in the right path?
Discuss.

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

I think the problem with school is they’re to attached, they won’t let you try new things, it’s always the basics. doing things like programming at home is better i believe rather than doing the VERY basics at school for 5 thousand years. They should let you develop at a standard you think you’re at, not force you to learn something you’ve done over and over.

Read full topic
item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

The School and you guys confirm that I don’t have any success in anything so I can’t really answer on the first one.

Good grades is the same as being smart. Some people in my class are plain stupid but good grades because they work their ass off. And some people like me get good grades and don’t really do anything to get it.

Much of the school is bullshit for me, I forget most things in less than a year.

Read full topic
item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

listenir:

School can help, It’s an important part of growing up in my opinion, it teaches you somewhat respect for others and how people behave in certain situations. Sometimes it can be bad, I.e. fights, bullying but it can be good life experience when you experience what it’s like and what you can do. School may not teach you as much knowledge to become a programmer or anything like that, but it teaches you the basics and how you should behave to be accepted as a member of the community.

I think high school is more important for general education than for specific education. It kind of teaches you what is right and wrong.

Read full topic

item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @cooper cooper
item.description:
@cooper wrote:

Does your success come from school?
It depends on what you consider ‘success’. In my sense, partially - I view success as understanding and knowing as much as possible, however not just in a scholastic sense, also in a person-to-person sense. My class in epistemology as well as ones that build analytical and critical thinking skills certainly have helped me, but social experiences with others also plays a major role. Although, I would not have had many of these experiences if not for school, however that is the social aspect and I wouldn’t consider that under school’s education.
Do you believe your grade in school defines how intelligent you are?
I do not believe this to be true. Grades are affected by multitudes of internal and external influences - the difficulty of your classes, your mental condition, your physical condition to an extent, your desire/effort, and the teacher and source material you are given. This is partially why I abhor the American educational system, however I understand that ‘success’ is most likely different to a capitalist looking for employees compared to my definition of it.
Does it truly affect your future and opportunity toward success, or is it only a stepping stone in the right path?
Again, it depends on what you consider ‘success’. It may affect your future, but like grades, there are always internal and external influences that can take prevalence.

Read full topic

la­wl:

if school is supposed to teach you social skills, then fuck, its failed for me

Hahaha, I didn’t exactly turn out overly extroverted myself. Now that I’ve been in uni for a few years, I’ve changed. Most of the people I went to high school with were deadbeats anyway who just aren’t worth the time or effort.

item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:11, topic:330896”][quote author=la­wl link=topic=427267.msg3138169#msg3138169 date=1267239243]
if school is supposed to teach you social skills, then fuck, its failed for me
[/quote]
School made me hate other people. The way people act is extremely ridiculous.[/quote]It’s an opportunity. Everything is a choice. Your grades are voluntary as well as how much you socialize with your peers.

@Frell - by learning social skills, it doesn’t mean you have to cope with any given individual. It’s just your understanding of what’s acceptable and what’s not when you’re having a conversation.

item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:6, topic:330896”]what you learn in school in terms of course content is completely useless. the rest however, is essential.[/quote]To add to this, my Chemistry teacher has said himself that it isn’t what you learn in school, but rather how you learn it. School is a practice of “learning how to learn”. The establishing of study techniques, increasing your ability of understanding. If you were to put 16 year old deprived of an education in a simulation that required a decent amount of problem solving along with a 16 year old that has completed his expected amount of years in school, the educated 16 year old would potentially solve it quicker and or better. Be it any subject given to the two of them, the educated 16 year old has gone ~10 years of school functioning on a slate that has required consistency and efficiency giving him the upper hand in the scenario. Without any guidelines or format, it’s difficult to solve something that requires specifications that one cannot fathom.

Read full topic

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“The Reaper X, post:1, topic:330896”]I’ve posted this on Moparscape, but Fat_Cookies suggested I try this discussion as well as a few others on Moparisthebest. I figured I’d get better responses as well, so…

School is a source of education. But, not everyone pursues the rest of their life based on what they learn in their classes. To some people, the classes they’ve taken in school were just as valuable as lunch.

Do you believe your grade in school defines how intelligent you are? Does it truly affect your future and opportunity toward success, or is it only a stepping stone in the right path?

Discuss.[/quote]

It really does not define how intelligent you are. I see intelligence and knowledge as two separate things. Intelligence allows you to gain knowledge. Knowledge means the things you know. Someone with a lot of knowledge is someone who is a replacement for a (small) library. Someone who is intelligent is someone that can create a new library.

Knowledge is theory, intelligence is the ability to create new theory.

Read full topic
item.source: Does your success come from school?

item.title: Does your success come from school?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:2, topic:330896”]

To expand on that, I would say the things my parents (who I would consider to be very intelligent), particularly my father, have taught me have had a far greater value than anything I’ve learned in school.[/quote]I concur with the small addition that is really depends on your level of education. Anything from pre-school up to college is completely useless for me because it is all either common sense or things i have had an ongoing interest in.
